snippet.textDisplay:
MESSAGE TO DEONTAY WILDER:

In order to beat Tyson Fury you have to... you really have to become a defensive fighter. YOU ARE NOT GOING TO BEAT HIM WITH THAT RIGHT HAND. He is two quick. He knows your strength and he also knows your weakness. You have to become a defensive fighter. Play defense from round 1 to 5 and them his stamina is going to decrease and then you start going in on him. Coming out of it trying to dog him IS NOT GOING TO WORK. Also from round 1 to 5 you need to just jab him and play defense. Run around the ring get him tired. I hope you or the Wilder get this message before the 3rd Fight. Be the Wise fighter. Dont let him hold you, dont let him get to close to you you suppose to have space. From round 1 to 7 you did none of this in the second fight. BE WISE WITH FURY. Because he is a fighter that really knows your game plan. You have to show him different in the next Fight. GO WILDER!!!!!!!!!

snippet.textDisplay:
There were multiple reasons why Wilder got the worse beating of his life. It's easy to say now after the fact, but it has become clear now:
1. Wilder said Fury changing trainer/team was sign of weakness. It was actually Fury's strength. His team gave Fury better prep and tactics for this fight. New ideas and learning
2. On the trainers/team, Wilder's has got to be the worse of any world champion. We got the silent Breland who in an interview before the fight said there was no way Fury would try to KO Wilder. He did not prepare his fighter for a plan B, which is shocking. Even after we saw Fury was coming forward, Breland gave no orders to change in the corner. Like watching an oncoming car crash in slow motion but not turning the wheel. Deas seems like a nice guy but he's totally out of his depth compared to guys at Kronk gym. The other guys in Wilder's camp, watching the videos, seems a mix of friends and yes men, too afraid or without authority to challenge Wilder or correct his mistakes, like his 'fitness coach'.
3. On the trainers, this same tired group that have been with Wilder for years have never taught him some of the boxing fundamentals. It is shocking and this was on display in his mauling - he can't move his head or change levels to defend himself, he just leans back upright all the time. He can't throw proper hooks or combos. His footwork is poor. He couldn't do anything to keep Fury from advancing as he can't box properly, just flings a jab and that right hand.
4. Tactics. Not only did Fury beat Wilder with better tactics on the night, he also beat him with mental warfare before the fight. He/his team are smart. This is a fight, you do what you can to get advantages. I'm talking about Fury apparently bluffing with his weight to confuse Wilder at the weigh in (Davison said he wasn't actually 270lbs). Confusing Wilder by making his 'I'm going to KO you' seem like a bluff to which Wilder and his team completely fell for. Then we had Wilder going around giving interviews saying 'I like Fury as a person'. What kind of frame of mind is this before a do or die fight?
5. Wilder's ego. Being surrounded by yes men and defending his title 10 times against mostly poor opposition would have the effect to inflate anyone's ego, but Wilder before this fight seemed slightly deluded. This meant he has never fixed his fundamental flaws, and thought he could beat a world class boxer with only a limited plan A.
snippet.textOriginal:
There were multiple reasons why Wilder got the worse beating of his life. It's easy to say now after the fact, but it has become clear now:
1. Wilder said Fury changing trainer/team was sign of weakness. It was actually Fury's strength. His team gave Fury better prep and tactics for this fight. New ideas and learning 
2. On the trainers/team, Wilder's has got to be the worse of any world champion. We got the silent Breland who in an interview before the fight said there was no way Fury would try to KO Wilder. He did not prepare his fighter for a plan B, which is shocking. Even after we saw Fury was coming forward, Breland gave no orders to change in the corner. Like watching an oncoming car crash in slow motion but not turning the wheel. Deas seems like a nice guy but he's totally out of his depth compared to guys at Kronk gym. The other guys in Wilder's camp, watching the videos, seems a mix of friends and yes men, too afraid or without authority to challenge Wilder or correct his mistakes, like his 'fitness coach'.
3. On the trainers, this same tired group that have been with Wilder for years have never taught him some of the boxing fundamentals. It is shocking and this was on display in his mauling - he can't move his head or change levels to defend himself, he just leans back upright all the time. He can't throw proper hooks or combos. His footwork is poor. He couldn't do anything to keep Fury from advancing as he can't box properly, just flings a jab and that right hand.
4. Tactics. Not only did Fury beat Wilder with better tactics on the night, he also beat him with mental warfare before the fight. He/his team are smart. This is a fight, you do what you can to get advantages. I'm talking about Fury apparently bluffing with his weight to confuse Wilder at the weigh in (Davison said he wasn't actually 270lbs). Confusing Wilder by making his 'I'm going to KO you' seem like a bluff to which Wilder and his team completely fell for. Then we had Wilder going around giving interviews saying 'I like Fury as a person'. What kind of frame of mind is this before a do or die fight?
5. Wilder's ego. Being surrounded by yes men and defending his title 10 times against mostly poor opposition would have the effect to inflate anyone's ego, but Wilder before this fight seemed slightly deluded. This meant he has never fixed his fundamental flaws, and thought he could beat a world class boxer with only a limited plan A.

snippet.textDisplay: Absolutely over the moon for Fury, I'm a huge fan of his here in the UK. However I do feel for Wilder, as I do for any fighter in his position. Such a tough game the fight game.. I'm glad his corner threw the towel in, his legs were gone, his balance was gone, and he looked exhausted hurt and bewildered. No sense in him taking unnecessary damage.
snippet.textOriginal: Absolutely over the moon for Fury, I'm a huge fan of his here in the UK. However I do feel for Wilder, as I do for any fighter in his position. Such a tough game the fight game.. I'm glad his corner threw the towel in, his legs were gone, his balance was gone, and he looked exhausted hurt and bewildered. No sense in him taking unnecessary damage.

snippet.textDisplay:
It was the perfect decision of fury to add fight at 273 instead of his 250 ish the first fight. That added weight didn't slow him down but it did put back end on his punch. The fight was over when wilder turned away and took that thump behind his ear..
Fury's punch didn't have to snap neck braking power but the side behind them was far too much for wilder to take.
It was the weight and focus on harder punching that made the difference.

snippet.textDisplay: He was in there with a more experienced (crafty) fighter, who put a good game plan together.  At some point, Wilder needs to realize he has to improve his boxing skill...whether it's technique or defense.  I don't buy that he is too old to improve. Look at fighters who fought well at late age: George Foreman, Bernard Hopkins, FLOYD MAYWEATHER$$, MANNY PACQUIAO.  He can improve, mainly in the IQ area.  He (Wilder), looked confused and amateurish. No head movement, stood straight up, backing up. Did he have a game plan? He needed to study Fury, like they studied him.  As a professional, and having fought him once. You should know the opponent somewhat.  Mark Breland ( a Veteran Boxer) should be thanked for throwing in the towel.  Getting beaten and going out on your face..UNNECESSARY!!!  Being able to improve and fight another day.. PARAMOUNT!!!!  Wilder, it's an entertainment sport (yes).  But ultimately it's how you feed your family (it's a job). Put the pride aside, improve and FIGHT ON!!!!.
snippet.textOriginal: He was in there with a more experienced (crafty) fighter, who put a good game plan together.  At some point, Wilder needs to realize he has to improve his boxing skill...whether it's technique or defense.  I don't buy that he is too old to improve. Look at fighters who fought well at late age: George Foreman, Bernard Hopkins, FLOYD MAYWEATHER$$, MANNY PACQUIAO.  He can improve, mainly in the IQ area.  He (Wilder), looked confused and amateurish. No head movement, stood straight up, backing up. Did he have a game plan? He needed to study Fury, like they studied him.  As a professional, and having fought him once. You should know the opponent somewhat.  Mark Breland ( a Veteran Boxer) should be thanked for throwing in the towel.  Getting beaten and going out on your face..UNNECESSARY!!!  Being able to improve and fight another day.. PARAMOUNT!!!!  Wilder, it's an entertainment sport (yes).  But ultimately it's how you feed your family (it's a job). Put the pride aside, improve and FIGHT ON!!!!.
